reviewText: It's easy to dig on Batman & Robin.  It's corny.  It's unreal.  It's too long.  It's got too many characters.  It's got too much eye candy.  It's got too many plot strands.  Even so, it's not as bad as you might think.  I once thought it was the worst films ever, but have since come to see it in a different light.  It's certainly not the best Batman film (Batman Begins has that honor), though it's not as bad as the low budget 1940s serials and I like it better than the 1966 Batman movie.This film is a good representation of the nonsensical comic era of the 1960s and works well if you realize that it's not meant to be serious.  While other Batfans who grew up, like me, on Year One, The Killing Joke, The Dark Knight Returns, A Death in the Family, etc might find this childish and ridiculous it does have some basis in the Batman comics of the 1960s just as Batman Forever is very similar to the 1940s, 50s, and 60s lighter Batman comics.  Take it as it is and you might enjoy it.  Insist on having a Dark Knight Batman of the first two films, Begins, and the Animated Series and you'll absolutely hate this film.  Take it as a campy adventure of the Caped Crusader based on 1960s Batman comics and you might actually enjoy it.Granted, this film could do without Batgirl and Ban and could lose 20 minutes or so, but it's still enjoyable if you understand what it is.  Most raised with Frank Miller's darker Batman find that hard.The new Special Edition is excellent as well.  The Extras are well worthwhile and explain that the toy companies and just about everyone else has input on this film.  I'd recommend buying all four in the new Batman Anthology - it's worthwhile.
summary: Not as bad as your might think
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, Michael Keaton, then, Val Kilmer, and now, George Clooney has taken over as the Caped Crusader in this fourth episode of the Batman series.  As with the previous films, Batman faces a new challenge from new enemies in this movie.  Two new villians are introduced in this film.  The first is Mr. Freeze, played by Arnold Schwarzenegger.  Before turning to crime, Mr. Freeze was a successful doctor who was working on a cure for McGregor's disease, with which his wife was suffering.  A mistake occurred in the lab, and Dr. Fries fell into a container of freezing liquid.  As a result, he is forced to keep himself in a cold environment or risk death.The other villian is Poison Ivy, played by Uma Thurman.  She as well suffered an accident, and now she has taken on the characteristics of plantlife as her powers.  She uses her powers to pit Batman and Robin against one another, while she and Freeze join forces to rule Gotham City.An ally appears for Batman and Robin as well.  Barbara Wilson, played by Alicia Silverstone, is Alfred's niece.  She's on break from school and arrives for a visit.  Its not long before she discovers information from Alfred about Bruce and Dick, and soon, she's joined the crime fighting team as Batgirl.Will Batman, Robin, and now Batgirl be strong enough to stop Poison Ivy and Freeze, or will Gotham be turned into a giant iceberg?I thought this was a good but not great movie.  Usually, a series that has several sequels looses appeal and viewers as the series goes on.  Naturally, I thought the original Batman was by far the best movie of the series, but the three sequels have been good in their own rights, as is the case with Batman and Robin.George Clooney does a surprisingly good job as Batman, and Alicia Silverstone and Chris O'Donnell are good as well, but this film belongs to Arnold Schwarzenegger.  He is excellent as Mr. Freeze, and he still has his trademark one-liners in this movie.  Although the series has lost a little momentum since the first movie, I still recommend this movie.  The acting is good and the special effects, especially the freezing effects, are very good.  Watch and see the continuing adventures of the Bat.

reviewText: Let me point out something right off the bat (no pun intended), this movie doesn't even deserve one star.  When Joel Schumacher took over the Batman movie franchise with Batman Forever, it was a pleasant surprise.  He infused some color with the Darkness and made it more like a comic rather than a freak fest that Tim Burton had done with Batman Returns.  Alas, his artistic touch went psychopathically rampant and homosexually insane (nipples on the costumes?) with Batman and Robin.The person I feel sorry for the most is George Clooney, and thankfully he still has a liberal sense of humor about it, saying to this day `I tried to kill that franchise'.  Believe me George, it wasn't your fault.  Joel Schumacher, who has been known to actually make decent movies (A Time To Kill, Flatliners, The Lost Boys, 8mm) somehow finds his creative license going WAY out of control.  He takes Batman; a dark, self obsessed, single minded and violent character and turns him and Robin (Chris O'Donnell) into the Neon Avengers.  Poor Arnold Schwarzenegger, playing Mr. Freeze,  probably wanted to just play a good villain again since his Terminator days had been sorely missed, is given the most hammed up dialogue of any villain and sent into action with a set of neon refrigerator parts strapped to his chest.  Alivia Silverstone, given even worse dialogue (oh, who am I kidding, it's all crap) steps in and falls flat on her face as Batgirl.  Don't get me started on the fact that they changed her origin (you could hear fans protesting when they heard that in the theater).  She was the Police Commissioners daughter (Commission Gordon, dismissed again in this movie) throughout the entire span of Batman's existence and suddenly they want to turn around and make her Bruce Wayne's niece!?  And then there's Bane; a super dangerous and intelligent villain in the comic (the guy actually defeated Batman and broke his back) has been downgraded to a mindless muscle pet for the villian.  What the hell?  And then there's Uma Thurman as Poison Ivy, looking beautiful and trying so, so, so hard to maintain her dignity throughout this entire disaster.  I feel sorry for all the actors who had to endure this mess.Batman and Robin was a travesty that got way out of hand and had me longing for Tim Burton's Batman movies, which I never thought I would do.  I kept wondering how Schumacher could justify the hack and slash treatment he had given to the franchise.  He seemed to be trying to relive the glory days of the old TV show with Adam West.  Not a good idea.  Didn't Tim Burton prove that people wanted a dark and intimidating Batman with the first two movies?  I can't put the entire blame on Schumacher though, I'm sure that it came down to merchandising as well.  All the vehicles, costumes, characters...all created so they could have a complete line of action figures.  This movie was made at a time when Warner Brothers was pumping the Batman franchise for every nickel it could.  And they were doing the same for Superman, which is why that movie was never made until last year.  Thankfully when the new CEO took over at the turn of the century, changes were made and a REAL Batman movie was created.  Forget the Michael Keaton, Val Kilmer, George Clooney Batmans.  I like the actors and admire their efforts in what they did, but it wasn't their fault.  [...]
summary: Talk about leaving a bad taste in your mouth...
Title: N/A

reviewText: You may have heard of this movie.Or you'd rather not.Joel Schumacher and screenwriter Akiva Goldsman, continuing the success of Batman Forever, once again collaborated to destroy everything that made the first two Batman movies so fascinating and appealing to the eyes and the ears. Mr. Freeze (played by Schwarzenegger, who bizarrely got top billing and $20 million) is stealing ice diamonds to find a cure for his frozen wife. Batman and Robin (George Clooney and Chris O'Donnell respectively) attempt to stop Mr. Freeze but problems are complicated by the arrival of Poison Ivy (Uma Thurman, in a role that almost demolished her career before her resurrection with Kill Bill), who flirts with the Caped Crusaders, particularly Robin, driving a wedge between the duo. Because that's what a superhero movie needs: an unnecessary romantic subplot.Tim Burton was going for the inner torment that sustained the Caped Crusader in Batman and Batman Returns. In Batman & Robin, Schumacher replaces such complexity with laughable one-liners, witless dialogue and Bat suit nipples. Burton's worlds were gothic labyrinths of imposing skyscrapers and fertile shadows that suggested film noir and the German expression. Schumacher turns Burton's Gotham City into an amusement park of garish lights, vulgar colors and naked statues that size of the Chrysler Building. Joker's sample line was "You can call me Joker. As you can see, I'm a lot happier." Mr. Freeze's lines? "Chill.", "What killed the dinosaurs? The ice age?" "Stay cool, Bird boy." "Tonight's forecast: a freeze is coming". One can be hard pressed to find a more vulgar and tasteless spectacular since the works of Cecil B. DeMille. At least DeMille's spectacles were good for a laugh. This, on the other hand, is good for an interrogation.Nor is this movie helped by the performances, which range from unintentionally hilarious to painfully bad. While Schwarzenegger gets a pass due to the fact that he is not exactly a thespian, other actors like O'Donnell, Clooney, Thurman and Silverstone deliver dismal acting that would make Ed Wood hang in his head in shame. Not even the veterans Pat Hingle and Michael Gough can make the writing material passable as their performances are straitjacketed by Goldsman's dangerous script.There are times when movies become so self-destructively awful that you cannot help but watch in fascination on how it all went wrong. Batman & Robin is a rarity: a hideous product that has no redeeming value for even the most bizarre tastemakers. While Burton's legacy in the Batman franchise was elevating it to gothic splendor, Schumacher's legacy was burying it six feet under with its camp overkill. Never has $100 million been so wastefully spent on such an overblown and unintelligent catastrophe. It'd be tempting to call Batman & Robin the worst movie of the nineties but it's got stiff competition in Hudson Hawk, North, Patch Adams, Showgirls and The Good Son. Therefore, I'll let the readers to decide on what pile of garbage stinks the most.Batman & Robin is both currently available separately and on the Batman Anthology 1989-1997 set that includes all four Batman movies, the first two directed by Burton and the latter two by Schumacher. One does not have to guess which pair of movies is better.

reviewText: This is and will always be THE worst superhero movie of all time. Joel Shumacher made this Batman so ridiculous, naive, unappealing and laughable. The costume, the acting, the plot, the whole thing was a downright failure. I watched this movie when I was 8 years old and I found it stupid. 16 years later, I find it worse. In this movie, you see him dancing and cracking jokes? Poison Ivy was passable, was not that bad. Bane was a joke, a green, ivy drenched small in stature character with no lines but screaming and saying: "Bane".Then you have Robin, O' Donnell did a good Robin, I can't complain, Robin is mostly whiny and vengeful character so his interpretation and role was good. Batgirl was horrible, first of all being blonde kinda changed the whole aspect of the character, secondly, Batgirl wasn't such a rebel like in this movie and third, making her Alfred's niece? What a turnaround is that?!This movie was more of a spoof, a horrible movie all in all. reviewText: After the dissapointing Batman and Batman Returns, I was ready to give up on the Batman film series. Tim Burton had turned the campy, fun loving Batman of my youth into some kind of dark knight, seeking vengence, draped in shadows. It was simply horrible. Then Schumacher came along and showed a lot of promise with Batman Forever, which had some good parts (Holey Rusted Metal, Batman!) but for the most part was still too dark. It had Jim Carrey in it, I should have been rolling in the aisles! Then with Batman and Robin he gave me what I really wanted, Bat-nipples, comic-book dialogue and colors, and the thinly veiled sexuality references that I love so well. It's been five years since this movie came out, when will Schumacher direct another, and when will George Clooney stop wasting his time with garbage like Ocean's Eleven and Out of Sight. As Arnold might say: "This movie was cool as ice!"
summary: Joel Schumacher: Savior of the Bat franchise

reviewText: Who do you blame for a catastrophe of this nature?  Director Joel Schumacher?  Screenwriter Akiva Goldsman, who also penned the atrocious "Lost in Space?"  Unfortunately, poor George Clooney gets most of the blame, but why pick on him?  After all, so many people worked on this movie; he was just the guy in the Bat-suit.From its grotesquely overblown set-design to its nonsensical plot, from the insipid one-liners to the woefully miscast Arnold Schwarzenegger, this is one titanically bad movie.  Titanic in that it's huge!  It's bigger than you or me... and it's headed this way!  The sets and action sequences dwarf Arnold, Clooney, and Chris "Robin" O'Donnell.  So much so, they could've been played by Munchkins from "The Wizard of Oz," which, come to think of it, is a movie more in touch with reality than "Batman & Robin."In other Gotham City news, Uma Thurman vamps the Dynamic Duo as Poison Ivy, and Alicia Silverstone plays her "Clueless" character, Cher, in a rubber suit.  And under all the sparkly explosions and chrome machinery is a plot about some big, cold guy (our boy, Arnold) in clumsy, shiny armor who wants to freeze Gotham City.  I defy you to care, or even understand.You will see every dollar spent on this thrill ride.  Almost everything glows like those sticks you snapped as a kid, or else has infinitely detailed vents and edges; it all screams: "We've been designed to the nth degree!"  Believe me, it looks like it costs billions.  And yet the result is so infantile, so nonsensical, it's thrilling in an unintended way.  It's grotesque even, the film equivalent of conspicuous consumption.  Holy Event Film, Batman!
summary: Holy Flops of the Cow Variety!

reviewText: After the events of Batman Forever, the caped crusader (George Clooney) and Robin (Chris O'Donnell) go after a mad scientist named Victor Fries aka Mr. Freeze (Arnold Schwarzenegger) who steals diamonds and all that as he wants to find a cure for his frozen dying wife Nora. A female scientist named Pamela Isley (Uma Thurman) was working on formula to make mutant plant-animal creatures until she snoops at her boss's lab where Dr. Jason Woodrue (John Glover) has created Bane (Jeep Swanson) and he finds out what she did as he accidentally mutates her into a sexy siren called Poison Ivy where her kiss can be literally deadly to any man as she with Bane go to Gotham City for a diabolical plan. Alfred (Michael Gough) is dying as he is suffering from McGregor syndrome as his beloved niece Barbara (Alicia Silverstone) who has came to see her uncle and visit Gotham, Dick Grayson begins to fall in love with Ivy as he has a desire for her and the two villains become a duo as they want to rule the city then the world.This movie is an absolute total mess of a movie! where to begin? where to begin? the screenplay by Akiva Goldsmith is absolutely dismal and poorly written and Schumacher's direction is quite lazy here as i'm sure he did this movie for the money. This is also quite a homoerotic film with nipples on Batman and Robin's costumes including close-ups to their butts and crotches in the suit-up scenes including some half naked male statues, the acting is quite bad despite a nice cast and the effects are ok but not quite on par with the same year's Fifth Element or Titanic or Starship Troopers. The dialogue was absolutely dismal even with those stupid ice puns Mr. Freeze makes. I saw this in theaters when i was 15 at one of the 3 major malls in Albuquerque at Cottonwood Mall and i thought it was the worst cinematic experience i ever endured in my life, not only that but i thought they butchered some stuff of the characters even if Schumacher was ripping off that "Heart of Ice" episode of TAS and changed Barbara's origin to being Alfred's niece. I was suffering when i saw this in theaters as i felt like i was being beaten by a bully as i sat through the whole thing as i booed at the end and wanted my 7 bucks back. Nothing could redeem this mess after Schumacher killed the franchise and the series was dead as a doornail.The PQ on this blu-ray is excellent but yet they say that you can't polish a turd yet for a piece of total crap it looks good on HD and the SQ is good too and there is extras like commentary, documentaries and featurettes, music videos, heroes and villains profile, additional scene and trailer. This blu-ray even has an apology by Schumacher for making this stinker and please folks, avoid this rubbish like the plague and be glad Nolan rebooted the franchise with his excellent trilogy.
summary: An abomination! killed the Batman franchise for good!

reviewText: Was director Joel Schumacher even trying with this movie?  Was he thinking that with all of the "really neat" colors, lights and sets of his previous Batman movie, BATMAN FOREVER, that even more of the same to the point of overload would make this one better?  Did he think "auto pilot" was a way to do this movie?  Does anybody who watch this movie lose count of just about every predictable cliche, or ridiculous catch lines?  I'm sorry, I enjoyed all of the Batmans, including FOREVER, but this one is strictly for a kiddie set who can more easily enjoy the groan inducing lines, scene leaping from one to another showcasing the same old stunts, colorful backdrops and doesn't mind the corny maniacal laughter and glowering, particularly from poor Arnie (who looks utterly ridiculous in his Mr. Freeze suit, not to mention being the one spitting out most of the movies stupid lines that catagorized him in the "dumb action star" role in the first place.)  BATMAN AND ROBIN is also slated for someone who liked the old TV show's campiness and wants to see it one the big screen with a huge budget.  The story, well it goes something like this.  Batman and Robin must stop Mr. Freeze and Poison Ivy from taking over the world.--The End.  I'm not wasting anymore time with this movie, I have wasted enough precious seconds.

reviewText: Batman & Robin. For the longest time I've know about the reputation for this film and have been so curious on just how bad this film really is. Picked it up for $6 one night and gave it a try. Folks, it's bad. A complete mess filled with chlichés, puns, bad acting, and a bat-credit card. In this film, Arnold Schwarzenegger plays as the main villain Mr. Freez who is looking for a cure for a rare disease his wife contracted. He decides to freeze Gotham and hold it for ransom for billions of dollars to produce a cure... And saying bad one liners and ice puns in the process. Don't like one lines and ice puns, don't worry! There's only 20 million in this movie!! Chris O' Donnell(Robin) stated that while filming for this movie, he felt like he was in a toy commercial... Wow. Every single person in this movies seems to have a wire on them as they can absurdly throw and jump amazing distances. In one frame, you can see ice wobbling on a car. Really?! Folks, don't watch this unless you're very curious like I was. Bane is also in this movie.. Just a Sasquatch on chemo.
summary: Batman and the Death of a Franchise

reviewText: This movie was wrong on so many counts. Not one of the characters was well played. George Cloony played a good Bruce Wayne, but a bad Batman(alhtough better than Val Kilmer). Chris O'Donnell is the most annoying character of the movie returning as Robin. Alicia Silverstone brings her teenie-bopper fame to the screen, badly I might add, as Batgirl. Uma Thurman does an OK job as Poison Ivy. And Arnold Schwarzenegger does a TERRIBLE job as Mr. Freeze. The character couldn't get worse. The plot [was poor]. I don't even want to review the plot. And the scenery just got 1,000,000 times worse. There isn't one scene with a dark, gothic look. Everything is lit up. And what is with Batman and Robin attending banquits?? They only come out to fight crime, not socialize. But the only reason this movie got 3 stars is because it is Batman. Batman can never be a movie that you hate. No matter how bad they can get, no matter how bad the scenery, acting, or script can get, its still Batman and it is still fun. This is the worst of the series but still worth a buy to complete the Batman collection."Batman & Robin" runs for 2 hours. It is rated PG-13 for scenes of some strong, yet cartoonish, violence, and very breif sexuality.

reviewText: This review does not contain any specifics about the plot and no spoilers.  See other reviews if you want to know what the movie is about.I saw Batman & Robin (1997) for the first time just two months ago, a full 13 years after it came out.  I never bothered to see it in 1997 and the years since its release because I heard how terrible it was, so I didn't want to touch it with a 22-foot-long pole.  When I was watching it back in June I was thinking, "This isn't as bad as people make it out to be".  Of course it helps tremendously that I'm a fan of the fun and campy Batman stuff, whether it's the 1960s ABC TV show or Batman: The Movie (1966).  I also like the darker, gothic, more serious Batman movies, such as Batman (1989), Batman Returns (1992), Batman Begins (2005), and The Dark Knight (2008).  But I need to laugh once in a while, whether I'm laughing WITH a movie or AT a movie.  This is where Batman & Robin comes in.  This movie can serve an important purpose - it can provide lots of laughs for you.  By simply watching the campiness, absurdity, cheesy lines, funny looking costumes, and the non-serious plot, you'll probably laugh a lot.This movie reminds me a lot of the 1960s television series on ABC TV, with its brilliant colors, humor, and campiness.When Batman (1989) and Batman Returns (1992) came out, a lot of people said those movies were too dark and too serious, that they were so unlike the fun and campy TV series from 1966-1968.  So what did director Joel Schumacher do?  He answered the demands of the people  who wanted something less serious and more fun and campy.  Well, the audience (including some of the people who wanted camp) freaked when they saw this movie.  They said it wasn't dark enough and serious enough.  This is the very thing that a lot of people complained about in the first place - that Batman and Batman Returns were too dark and too serious.  So it ended up being a no-win situation.Personally, I find this movie very entertaining and never boring.  Never a dull moment.  It holds my attention.  I laugh with it and at it.  That counts for something.  Sure, it is totally cheesy with awfully bad lines at times, but these bad lines come off as funny.  Some of the costumes are funny looking, like Robin's and Batgirl's and even Mr. Freeze's.  Arnold Schwarzenegger plays Mr. Freeze and is totally funny in the role.  His lines, his costume, it all works.  George Clooney is a mediocre Bruce Wayne and Batman.  Chris O'Donnell is a pretty good Robin, but he's no Burt Ward (from the TV series).  Alicia Silverstone, who plays Barbara Wilson/Batgirl, is no Yvonne Craig, who plays Barbara Gordon/Batgirl in the TV series, but her performance is passable.  I think Uma Thurman, who plays Poison Ivy, carries this movie even more than Arnold Schwarzenegger does.  She has the best costume and is easily the best actor in the whole movie.  It helps that she's a looker as well.Overall, I thought this was at least an OK movie.  Fair to pretty good.  Definitely entertaining.  I wish I had seen it a long time ago.  I'll say this:  If you have always stayed away from this movie, give it a chance.  Rent it.  You'll probably laugh either with it or at it, but the bottom line is that you'll laugh.
summary: This movie wasn't as bad as I thought it'd be
Title: N/A

reviewText: Batman & Robin(1997) was a critical and commercial flop. It almost killed the Batman film franchise. It's the butt of jokes. Director Joel Schumacher apologized to people who hated it. It suffers from bad editing, plot holes, and campy humor. Arnold Schwarzenegger and George Clooney were miscast as Mr. Freeze and Batman. The film is also packed with product placement. I saw it on opening day in 1997 and I enjoyed it. I still get a warm, nostalgic feeling from watching it. Batman(George Clooney), Robin(Chris O' Donnell), and Batgirl(Alicia Silverstone) must stop Mr. Freeze and Poison Ivy(Uma Thurman) from taking over Gotham City. Batman & Robin "borrows a few pages" from the Captain Cold episode of The Flash(1990-1992). Poison Ivy yells "curses" in one scene. A Wizard of Oz(1939) reference, perhaps? Vivica A. Fox makes a brief appearance as Mr. Freeze's mistress. Batman & Robin is on par with a cheesy El Santo movie such as Operacion 67(1967).Elliot Goldenthal's energetic, over the top music score for Batman & Robin was awesome. It sounds "alive". Uma Thurman struggles to give a sincere performance as Poison Ivy. We get to see the late Michael Gough play Alfred Pennyworth for the last time. Alicia Silverstone was a sensual, photogenic Batgirl. She looks just as good as Yvonne Craig's version of Batgirl from TV's Batman. Arnold Schwarzenegger gives a sincere performance as Mr. Freeze even with his limited acting range. Patrick Stewart or Ben Kingsley would've been a more inspired choice to play Freeze. George Clooney is a good actor, but he was very wooden as Batman. Cindy Carol was a wooden Gidget. Chris O' Donnell works hard to play Robin, but he seems unfocused. John Dykstra's visual effects are solid and he worked on Spiderman(2002) years later. Batman Begins(2005) and The Dark Knight(2008) returned Batman to his dark, violent, gothic roots.  Batman & Robin(1997) was made a time when Batman had to "lighten up".

reviewText: Batman & Robin could be summed up in one word: Fun. Between Burton, Schumacher, Nolan, the 60's TV show, multiple cartoon series, and of course all of the comics there have been many versions of Batman over the decades. Schumacher took what Burton had started with the dark version of Batman in Batman('89) and Batman Returns and made it a little lighter in Batman Forever. Batman Forever did extremely well at the box office and exceeded everything that Warner Bros. was hoping it could do. With this in mind Warners decided to push Batman & Robin into an even lighter territory than Batman Forever. This caused a huge uproar with many Batman fans.The point of my review is to point out that even though Batman & Robin is a lighter version of Batman there still is much to enjoy and much fun to have in Batman & Robin. First off the story itself is very entertaining and action packed (even quite a bit more action packed than Nolan's movies). The movie also brings with it a campy style of story telling that is very reminiscent of the '60's TV show. I actually look at this as a positive because its just another part of a very large chunk of previous Batman lore. There are the very dark Batman movies which are also fantastic but this does an excellent job of showing off that not everything in the Batman universe must be dark. (Before anyone comes into my review to tell me how much better the darker versions are, please save yourself the time, because I absolutely do love those versions as well.)One great thing about Batman & Robin is actually Arnold Schwarzenegger. Many fans will complain that he is an awful Mr. Freeze, because he doesn't play the character dark enough. If you don't think of this movie like that, you might realize that in this movie its just Arnold being Arnold and that is a very good thing and makes this movie extremely enjoyable. All the actors performances in this movie were over-the-top and they were supposed to be as Joel Schumacher wanted this movie to be as close to a visual comic book as possible. Another great performance is given by Uma Thruman. She goes for as over-the-top as she can get and its fantastic.The biggest thing people complain about though is George Clooney, and that he was an awful Batman because he didn't play the part nearly dark enough. If I could have changed something about this movie it would have been to have had a darker Batman but that is not George's fault. He was just doing what he was told to do by Schumacher. And Schumacher was just doing what he was being told to do by Warners. The majority of Schumacher's films are quite dark, so I know if Warner's would have wanted a darker movie Schumacher could have given it to them, and I think he would have had Clooney portray Batman much differently.Having said that, even the lighter Batman in this movie still makes this a very enjoyable and very fun movie. Just don't try to take it overly seriously and you will have a very good time.
summary: Not nearly as bad as its made out to be.

reviewText: Okay so, Batman & Robin (1997) one of the worst, if not THE worst superhero movie ever made. If you look up "BATMAN & ROBIN/ JOEL SCHUMACHER" on YOUTUBE you will find director Joel Schumacher (PHONE BOOTH, 8mm) actually apologize for this movie. I hate to say it, but, his apology simply isn't enough! The only thing this film was lacking from Schumacher's vision was the "BAM!", "POW!" subtitles we used to see in the 1960's Adam West television show. Arnold Schwarzenegger (THE TERMINATOR, END OF DAYS) plays Mr. Freeze and my God is he just awful. The great Uma Thurman (PULP FICTION, THE AVENGERS)who plays Poison Ivy, is ALMOST as bad as Schwarzenegger. Then there's Chris O'donnell (BATMAN FOREVER, THE CHAMBER) as the "boy wonder" Robin. Need I say more on him? George Clooney(FROM DUSK TILL DAWN, THREE KINGS) is an okay actor, not very diverse, but, okay never the less. However, casting him as Batman is just a horrible joke on the audience. And then, just when you think we've seen all the horrible B.S. Schumacher can throw our way, him and his trusty screenwriter Akiva Goldsman (BATMAN FOREVER, A TIME TO KILL) throw in....Batgirl! Yeah, that's right, freakin' Batgirl, played by the lovely Alicia Silverstone (CLUELESS, EXCESS BAGGAGE). Trust me, the only thing going for this joke of a movie is it's looks. However, looks can be decieving and Batman & Robin fall flat on their heads.
summary: I know, I know two stars is two too much!!!

reviewText: I can't begin to describe how watching this film made me feel. it was somewhere between stubbing your toe and waking up Christmas morning and finding out everyone in your family forgot about you. That kind of mixture of sheer rage, pain, disappointment and the uncontrollable need to cry. This film was strictly made for those Batman fans who eat through a straw and wear a helmet everywhere they go. It is insulting to think that the big wigs at Warner Bros. thought they could distribute this to the same audience that liked the original "Batman" in 1989. Comparing the two is like comparing a toilet seat to a sunset. But seriously, this film was intended to make money and nothing more. They obviously didn't care about the legacy of what Bob Kane created or what fans had come to expect. Fans expect a more macabre feeling to their batman movies. Almost like a science-fiction/noir. This film is an adaptation more or less of the "Batman" T.V. series in the 1960's; not the true Batman that people like Frank Miller understand. With corny jokes from all around the cast (yes, even batman has a few), corny dialogue all throughout the movie, horrible acting, a sub-third grade level plot, and bad enough lighting, camera-working and original score to make it seem like a musical, this movie almost single-handedly brought down the entire Batman film franchise. If you are a total batman junkie and just can't get enough of all things Bat, than rent this movie, but I"m willing to bet that even you will want to burn it afterwards. This movie is so bad, its almost fun to watch for that reason, if it were not trying to be seriously passed off as a Batman movie.
summary: Can't we just all agree to forget this film was ever shot.

reviewText: Joel Schumacher's "Batman and Robin"(1997) isn't just a bad "Batman" movie, it's a bad movie in general. While the previous entry "Batman Forever"  was an enjoyable popcorn movie that was easy to watch and hard to review, "Batman and Robin" was a tough and tormenting misfire of a movie to watch and very easy to review. I am well aware of the burning hatred for this film. I hate it as well, with its seemingly unapologetic disregard for the characters, horrible script, and bad acting (except for a couple of performances). Like most Bat-fans, this was a film that to this day has been seared in my memory, and sure its one of the worst comic book movies or films in general of all time, and despite reviewing these films before, I saw this one again, and tried to look at it with fresh eyes, but unfortunately, to no success. To my surprise, however this film is hilarious in some moments. This film is so bad its funny!The Bad (I'll try to be as brief as possible, while mentioning the main things that don't make any sense)-George Clooney-Don't get me wrong, Clooney is a terrific actor, and now is an established director, but his "Batman" falls flat, while his Bruce Wayne is a vast improvement over Val Kilmer's, he has no business being in this movie.-Too Many one-liners, puns, and bad jokes! It seems that the crew and director went right back to the campy 60's look and feel that the series was originally intended to avoid, and it shows with Clooney's Batman. The character feels like Bruce just put on a mask and suit and decided to fight bad guys. Bruce doesn't come off as a man who became Batman, or who is intimidating towards criminals. Batman is a feared creature of the night, not a guy having a good time in a Bat-Suit.-Arnold Schwartzenegger's Mr. Freeze--despite a valiant effort by the actor, Arnold's Mr. Freeze comes off very, dull, and sarcastic--too many one liners from him, every line in the script is a cheesy joke.-Alicia's Batgirl--Despite Alicia being very sexy in the film (in my opinion) her character is completely wrong, and has some sort of connection to Alfred instead of Commissioner Gordon, and appears only as a means of saving Alfred, and help out the team with fighting crime, other than that she had no real motivations or goals of her own.-Bane---(Jeep Swenson RIP) despite Swenson's efforts, Bane remains my biggest complaint. He doesn't really serve any real purpose other than be the hired muscle of Poison Ivy. In the comics, Bane wasn't just a physical match for the Batman, but also a ruthless tactician, capable of master plans, and as in Knightfall, the man who broke the Bat. In the film, Bane is just a brute, who growls and rarely speaks, complete with luchador mask and tights.Julie Madison: Unlike Dr. Meridian from the previous film, Julie Madison is taken from the comics, and serves as Bruce's fiancee, only to be cut out of the film before the start of the third act. She literally disappears from the film entirely, without any sort of explanation, and does not return, at all, and doesn't conflict with Bruce's duties as Batman, like the other love interests did, from the previous film or even the first two Burton films.Too Many Plot Holes!1.) How is Batman able to slide down a giant dinosaur?2.) How are the dynamic duo able to find out where Freeze is after only 10 minutes in the film?3.) WTF is Coolio doing in a Batman movie?4.) The Bat Ice Skates? WTF?5.) The Bat Credit Card? What?6.) How is Batgirl Able to drive a motorbike on ice?7.)If Mr. Freeze needs to keep his body at subzero temperatures in order to survive, why is he smoking cigars at his hideout?8.)Another Day-glow Gang?9.) Flower Ball? Why?10.) "Peg" is the password to unlock the bat-cave? Why? Why is Barbara Wilson given access to Bruce and Dick's base of operations, and how is she able to become Batgirl without any formal combat or stealth training, or even education?11.)How is Alfred able to re-program his thoughts into the Bat-cave, and design (as well as manufacture) a fully operational suit for Barbara while he is ill with McGregor's Syndrome?12.) McGregor's Syndrome? WTF? Did they really make that up? Why?13.) Freezes Hockey Team Thugs? WTF? Most of them don't have faces!14.)Where did Freeze Get all of his hi-tech toys from?15.) How and why is Poison Ivy Connected to Bane?16.) Why do the dumb security guards (who remain way outgunned in all the Batman films to begin with) try to fight Mr. Freeze, who is in a super-powered suit?17.)How did Batman Unfreeze his Bat-mobile and manage to drive it all the way back to the bat-cave?18.)Batman and Robin as well as other costume vigilantes are actually trusted in Gotham???19.) Gordon Still has nothing to do in these movies? But he is the only officer that can disable the freezing gas when he and his cops raid Freeze's hideout?20.) Both Freeze and Ivy are vastly different characters (opposites in the comics) and have their own motivations in the comics--so why are they teaming up?21.) Freeze's origin Story was done correctly to some degree, but how would freezing the city help bring his wife back?22.) Alfred was in love with Margaret, his own sister? WTF?Final Thoughts!Overall, "Batman and Robin" is an abysmal film to say the least. Saying that it's the worst Batman film of 1990s would be damning it with faint praise. Only Uma Thurman's Poison Ivy and Michael Gough's Alfred are the only redeeming points of the movie, and as with the previous "Batman Forever", the stunt work is very well done. But everything else, is horrible, and like many other amazon customers, I am outraged that this film was even made! Not because of Schumacher's comedy-drama style approach to these films, but mainly for the bad acting, horrible script, and stunt casting of the villains (which every Batman film in this series has suffered from, to an extent) I am glad however, that Joel Schumacher apologized, which helped a great deal to me at least, as a viewer and Bat-fan. Too Bad it doesn't erase this film from my memory or anyone else's for that matter.Verdict:1 out of 5 stars!
summary: A Bad Movie--so bad it's hilarious

reviewText: What happens when a film franchise starts off with a massive success, follows that up with a smaller, somewhat unfocused sequel alienating some moviegoers, then comes back with a completely different tone, actors, director, etc., all of which leaves the movie studio (Warner Brothers in this instance) believing that lighter, more family friendly fare may be the way to go? Well, in the case of the once successful Batman franchise, the end result of this chain of events is the utterly campy, ridiculously acted, slap-in-the-face to the comic book fans, excuse of a movie titled "Batman & Robin"."Batman & Robin" follows the Dynamic Duo (George Clooney as Batman and Chris O'Donnell as Robin) on yet another adventure as they must take on the villainous pair of Mr. Freeze (Arnold Schwarzenegger) and Poison Ivy (Uma Thurman). With Mr. Freeze attempting to freeze all of Gotham City's population to death so that Poison Ivy can remake the city in a more Earth-friendly image, Batman and Robin, along with newcomer Batgirl (Alicia Silverstone) joining the Bat-family, must work together as only a family can, in order to save Gotham City's citizens before time runs out.Where to begin? This is a tough one for me to determine a good starting point for my critique portion of the review, mostly because the movie is just so horrible, with very few good points, that I find myself unsure of what to criticize first. Oh well, let's just take the plunge and see what happens.First we have the story, written once again by screenwriter Akiva Goldsman ("Batman Forever"), which is one of the campiest, lamest one-liner ridden, with the cheesiest action scenes, little to no drama, and poorly acted, pieces of comic book garbage that I have seen come out of Hollywood since either "Superman 3" or "Howard the Duck". The plot is the thinnest of all of the four Batman films in the franchise, leaving me to wonder if Akiva didn't really feel all that into writing this installment and perhaps allowed a child to do most of the work for him, that's how low the quality is for the overall story in this movie. I thought perhaps given the tone of the previous film being so much lighter than the first two movies in the series that perhaps the franchise was heading into the direction of the 60's television series, but I held onto hope that no one wanted to see that again; apparently I was way wrong. Now, I can't blame the writer completely for the lighter direction this franchise took with this last installment (although I can blame him for how horribly it was written); apparently Warner Brothers felt that because with "Batman Returns" audiences complained about it being so dark and twisted, that with "Batman Forever" the tone needed to be much friendlier towards children and family audiences. So, due to the success that "Batman Forever" enjoyed, which was considerably more than that of "Batman Returns", the WB decided that the fourth installment in the series needed to go even lighter, essentially making the movie funnier, more outlandish, and almost completely devoid of any semblance of drama, basically just recycle the 60's television series with new actors and you'll have the movie "Batman & Robin".The second set of problems that I had with "Batman & Robin" is with returning director Joel Schumacher ("Batman Forever"), who took everything that I didn't enjoy about his previous effort, "Batman Forever", and multiplied it by ten for this movie. For instance, in the previous movie, Schumacher used a lot of neon and bright colors to lighten up the movie's atmosphere, which felt completely out of place in a Batman film; so, in "Batman & Robin" everything is brighter and utilizes tons of neon, to the point that it feels like every scene has some sort of neon color in it. Another issue I have with the director is that once more Joel chose to leave nipples on the costumes for Batman and Robin, and once again I say to this, "No nipples on the suits! Never in the history of the comic books or even in the really good film adaptations (which would exclude Joel's attempts) have there been nipples on the costumes, there's just no point to having them there!" My last major gripe with Joel Schumacher's direction was that the action scenes were so phony and cheesy that I had to roll my eyes as I watched some of the absolutely ridiculous things both the heroes and villains do in this movie. Every stunt has the feel of obvious wire work, and not very good wire work at that, and all of the fight choreography is so telegraphed that you can see what's coming a mile away! One last thing regarding the stunts, whoever decided to have Robin's motorcycle bust through a wall leaving a hole in the shape of the Robin symbol really should be slapped (and I'm thinking the guilty party is you, Joel Schumacher), because that is so stupid, that even kids point at that moment and laugh at how ridiculous a stunt that is.My third and final batch of complaints must be aimed at the cast of "Batman & Robin", all of which act as if Jim Carrey had been their acting coach, or should I say "over-acting". Now, I understand that given the lack of a decent script and questionable direction from the writer and director respectively, that the actors didn't have a whole lot to make do with; however, this isn't the first time a group of actors have had to make something out of nothing, and it's been done successfully many times over, just not in this movie. George Clooney who hadn't done very many feature films prior to this one, wasn't the greatest actor at this point in his career (today he is much more accomplished at his craft), and without a doubt George gives the weakest performance as Batman within this franchise. Michael Keaton knew to establish Bruce Wayne and Batman as two discernible characters, the same with Val Kilmer in "Batman Forever", but with George there was no distinguishing between Bruce Wayne and Batman other than the costume, because he played both sides to the character the exact same way. Chris O'Donnell was good as Robin, though not as interesting as he had been in the previous movie. This time around Robin seemed more like a spoiled brat than a superhero, which made Batman seem more like a nanny than the Caped Crusader. Michael Gough portrayed Alfred once more in this installment, and provided the only true source of drama for the entire movie, but even that aspect wasn't executed near as well as it should have been.With "Batman & Robin" we were also introduced to several new characters, none of which come close to capturing the true essence of what made those characters so great in the comics. Alicia Silverstone ("Clueless") as Batgirl was an alright choice, she wouldn't have been my first pick; however, she's a decent enough actress that I thought maybe she could do a good job. Well, she wasn't great, but that's not completely her fault because the story arc she is given is fairly weak all across the board, but her line readings were mostly flat and uninspired. Not to mention the fact that her origin has been altered to make her Alfred's niece instead of Commissioner Gordon's daughter, a decision that served as just another problem, in the already far too long list, this movie had going against it. Along with Alicia we also have Uma Thurman ("Kill Bill") as Poison Ivy. Now, I thought that Uma definitely looked the part of Poison Ivy, but the constant use of Earth inspired references throughout her dialogue began to grow tiresome, and she apparently felt that because she was playing a villain it would be the perfect opportunity for her to practice the Jim Carrey art of over-acting in every scene in hopes of getting attention, most of which fell pathetically flat. Lastly, we have Arnold Schwarzenegger (`The Terminator' series) as one of the worst bits of casting I have seen in a comic book inspired movie. In the comics, Mr. Freeze was a skinny man in a mechanized suit with a big freeze gun; obviously Arnold couldn't pull off the skinny man routine due to his physique, so his resemblance to the character's appearance was nowhere near accurate. Although, to the Casting Director's credit, DC Comics did change the appearance of Mr. Freeze to resemble more closely that of Arnold in the movie, so maybe the choice wasn't all that bad, to me it was just another example of how everyone associated with this movie did not take the source material seriously at all. Aside from Arnold's obvious physical difference to the character's initial appearance, his acting in this movie was alright, but just like Uma Thurman's character of Poison Ivy, writer Akiva Goldsman apparently felt that including as many ice-themed one-liners into his dialogue as possible would be a good idea. Wrong, all that decision did was made his character become incredibly annoying at an even faster rate than Poison Ivy's.Well, you may be wondering when I will get to the good points regarding this movie, because so far it's all been mostly negative. I do have a couple of positive things to say regarding "Batman & Robin", first I must say that as pathetic as the story was, it did contain some decent elements in regards to trust and family issues that Batman and Robin must face, although sometimes even this was done a little too heavy-handed that it was a bit on the annoying side. Another standout achievement for the movie, was that the special effects (given that this movie is 11 years old now) were very good, especially for the numerous "ice covered" or "freezing" sequences featured throughout the movie. The last good thing I can say for this movie is this... It ends! Yes, that is probably the best aspect this movie has going for it, the fact that eventually the movie ends. On the flip side of that, is once the movie ends, you're left with the nagging feeling of having wasted two hours of your life away that you'll never be able to get back, other than that it's all good though."Batman & Robin", if you haven't figured it out yet, is absolutely the worst installment in the Batman franchise that spanned from 1989 through 1997; however as pathetic as this movie is, for some reason it has the same appeal as that of the 1960's television series and movie. The movie's like a train wreck, you know the results are going to be horrifying, yet you can't seem to bring yourself to look away; although, this movie does push the limits of that sentiment a few times."Batman & Robin" is rated PG-13 for violence and sensuality.
summary: The Ridiculously Inept End to The Original Batman Franchise...

reviewText: Long before the film premiered, when the casting was announced, I knew this film was gonna be in trouble. Not because of new Batman George Clooney, just simply from once again..too many characters.Everything  including the kitchen sink is thrown into the mix here. George Clooney does  the best he can with what's given him to work with which isn't much. Had he  gotten the chance to work with Tim Burton, he might have succeeded. Chris  O'Donnell's Robin is in the same boat. Flavor of the month Alicia  Silverstone is slickly tacked on and compounds the problems of the  film.Our ol buddy Arnold, looks really cool with blue skin and bald look  and shiny silver armor, but is reduced to spouting dopey one liners. Uma  Thurman's Poison Ivy is somewhat interesting and on top of that is the  inclusion of Bane. Bane, a character who was part of an epic storyline in  the comic books as a brainy yet monstrously juiced up on steroids criminal  is reduced to Ivy's doormat here.The story? Akiva Goldsmith's paper-thin  story is just an excuse to show off the characters and special effects. The  film is filled with cheesy one liners amd you start wondering if Adam West  is gonna pop up somewhere. The brief bit dealing with Alfred's illness is  poignant but is given no room to work with.Joel Schumacher really went  to town with this one. The production design is way overkill bordering on  tasteless and tacky. The Batmobile and other vehicles are cheezy looking.  The Bat costumes worn during the climax are silly as well. Elliot  Goldenthal's music follows suite. Everything in this movie is style over  substance.Enough fun and games Joel & Akiva, time to take a hike. If  Batman is to return to the theaters, someone at Warner Bros. had best read  Year One, and adapt that to the letter.

reviewText: Last night, I just rewatched Tim Burton's Batman. It's even better than I remembered it. I grew up watching that movie.I have just had the fortune to witness Batman and Robin tonight. Quite frankly, it stinks. It is not a good movie at all and it's tragic that this wonderful series had to end this way. I just want to point out what I thought made it so bad.The movie was supposed to take place in Gotham, right? If so, why was it so bright? Why is there all kinds of colors and stuff? It's just not the Gotham I saw in the first Batman or Batman Returns.There are three villains in this movie. There's Mr. Freeze, Poison Ivy, and Bane. Bane doesn't really count, though, because he's simply an animal in this movie. The main villains are Freeze and Poison Ivy. Freeze utters some really stupid lines, which I will not repeat here since other reviewers have already done that. Poison Ivy tries to kiss every man she sees. There are also three heroes. They are Batman, Robin, and Batgirl. What I don't get is why they felt the need to put Batgirl in the movie. It seems that they just put her in for no reason. Also, Batman and Robin bicker throughout the movie. Robin wants to be more independent, and he is just downright annoying. When Poison Ivy puts her little spell on him, he gets even more annoying. He thinks Poison Ivy actually likes him and constantly picks fights with Batman about it. By the way, George Clooney plays Batman in this movie, and I don't know if he was a good choice. He is a good actor, but not the kind of actor that would be good at playing Batman.This is a pretty strange movie, and not the "good kind of strange" either. Like I pointed out earlier, Gotham is filled with all kinds of weird colors and stuff. It looks like a giant nightclub, even a funhouse! The Gotham in the Tim Burton's Batman had a comic book feel to it but it was more realistic and more darker than what we see in Batman and Robin. Also, there's one scene where the Alicia Silverstone character played a big part that I found really odd and just out place. It was a motorcycle racing scene. This was just such an odd scene. It was like something out of a post apocalyptic movie. The other characters you see in this scene look like people from The Road Warrior. It just didn't fit in with the rest of the movie. Another thing I would like to point is the rather unusual shots we get of Batman and Robin near the beginning. I leave it to you to decide what these shots mean, but they were really strange to me...Batman and Robin's existance is just unnatural and wrong. Some people say that this movie killed the Batman series and I don't find that hard to believe. I say to all those who haven't seen this movie, don't bother. It's not worth it. Stick with Batman and Batman Returns. Also, check out Batman Begins and The Dark Knight. Those two movies have been very successful in undoing the damage that this movie has done to Batman.

reviewText: They seriously went to the trouble of making a new Batman movie and THAT was all they could come up with?  First of all, wouldn't you think the guy playing BATMAN would get top billing? They spent too much time figuring out  who got the most money and what the action figures would look like and  forgot to come up with a plot.  The first two Batman movies got the dark  atmosphere of Gotham City right on.  "Forever" was actually a  step up from "Returns" cinematically speaking, but this one falls  right off the charts.  Clooney is the worst Batman yet and this is by far  the worst thing I've ever seen Arnold do (if Mr. Freeze's part had been  rewritten, I agree with an earlier reviewer who said Patrick Stewart should  have played the role anyway). O'donnel is boring at this point, and throw  Alicia Silverstone into the mix and you have two too many sidekicks.  Not  only is this the worst Batman Movie, it's one of the five worst movies I've  EVER seen.

reviewText: This fourth installment of the Burton/Schumacher "Batman" film series is a complete dud all the way around.  It is so unlike the 89 Batman, one can even argue if it is not a separate take on the comic myth altogether.  Schumacher's vision is way over the top, with more camp than the 60's Batman, without the subtle ability to still be mildly entertaining.Great comic characters such as Mr. Freeze are handled so poorly, that one sees an empty vision and it seems more like Schumacher grabbed a bunch of friends and said "Let's play Batman."  The problem is that this movie has too many adult themes so parents won't want to set through this with their kids nor let their kids go unguarded.  Further, it isn't fun enough for kids, who still today would probably like the 60's show.Clooney has the chin of Batman, but inside the jaw is made of glass.  His performance is tired and flat.  O'Donnell's Robin is just as boring as he was in the last movie.  Uma Thurman, normally reliable for a good performance is just silly as Poison Ivy.  The action is flat and the movie sets are obvious.  Batgirl's introduction creates too many characters and she is frankly a bore.  Arnold, is tasked to  provide silly comic relief form a character who can bring depth if any bothered to read the comic or just watch "Fir and Ice" from the animated series (sold on Amazon in Batman the Animated Series Vol. I) which is a superior form of storytelling.  Elliot Goldenthal's musical score is overbearing.

reviewText: If you try to look at it as a superhero story it's really, really, really, really awful, the kind of thing that Ed Wood would have directed if someone had handed him umpty-million dollars and not applied any direct adult supervision. It's one of the worst comic book adaptations ever made, proof positive that Joel Schumacher and Akiva Goidsman (how does this schmuck keep getting to write movies?) should be hunted down and killed. But if you look at it as the sort of gay fantasia that Dr. Fredric Wertham described in the more salacious parts of _Seduction of the Innocent_ it's actually quite brilliant.I mean really, look at how well the two of them accessorize, when they're about to leave the Batcave, George Clooney (in his Batman costume, complete with anatomically correct but completely gratuitous nipples) hops into his harsh angular Batmobile, with electric blue neon hood and hubcaps (so much for fighting crime hidden in the darkness) and drives out of the cave. Then Chris O'Donnell (in his Robin costume with yet more anatomically correct and completely gratuitous nipples) hops onto his Robincycle, which comes out of the ground in a large box reminiscent of the kind used for pieces of expensive, abstract jewelry and which has a neon interior. And there's the Batcave, the name just screams "homosexuality".  There has to be a leather bar somewhere with that name, and if there isn't anyone who wants to start such a bar could just look at the Batcave scenes from this movie if they needed ideas for the decor.I think that rather than try to go back to the kind of Batman that Batman fanboys want, probably the Dark Knight of Frank Miller's series of the same name, future filmmakers should take this gay Batman, which is the kind of thing that Julie Schwartz might have created if he were gay, and if Batman had been a 60's muscle magazine for mature men, rather than a comic book, and run it into the ground. Future directors should keep the sets from this movie, which capture that twisted essence of Gotham city that was created when Dick Sprang was doing the comic in the 1950s, and take the gay theme out of the closet. Perhaps Tony Kushner could write the next screenplay, or Paul Rudnick. Nathan Lane could play the Alfred the butler, George Clooney and Chris O'Donnell could reprise their roles as the Dynamic Duo and they could fight a new threat to Gotham City, a villain named "Miss Thing".Man, I am so onto something here!

reviewText: As a Batman fan, I hate this movie even more intensely than a non-Batman fan could ever hate it. This movie has Mr. Freeze (Arnold Schwartzenegger) stealing diamonds and freezing people. Then he teams up with Poison Ivy (Uma Thurman) after she busts him out of Arkham. He thinks Batman killed his wife, so he decides to freeze the entire world, and Ivy will use some man-eating plants to populate the World once humankind is extinct (with the exception of her and Freeze). But what about Bane? And how exactly would Ivy survive? We don't know.All four Batman movies have Bruce Wayne (George Clooney) awkwardly trying to explain to some love interest that he's a complicated and odd fellow - he is Batman afterall. In this movie, his girlfriend (Elle MacPherson) says she wants to marry him. Elle doesn't do anything except take up space in this movie, but she makes for some nice eye candy. Anyway, it's especially hilarious when Wayne's saying "There's things you don't know about me..." and so on, because it sounds like he's about to come out of the closet. Batman Returns mentions what became of Vicki Vale, and I like that. Schumacher never bothers to let us know what becomes of Catwoman, or Meridian, or if Wayne accepts Elle's wedding proposal. Characters are simply ignored and forgotten in Schumacher's movies. Batman Forever doesn't acknowledge the existence of Burton's movies. And this movie pretends that the first three movies don't exist (except for the clothes we see in an Arkham storage room).There's leaden acting from everyone in this movie - except from Schwartzenegger and Thurman. They're actually quite entertaining (most of the time). And of course, the villains overshadow the completely uninteresting title character. Like Jones and Carrey, the villains give the best performances in this movie. But that's not saying much.Wayne is WAY too cheerful. He's also an an environmentalist - so Wayne must be a VERY conflicted tycoon. The flashback sequences he has in both of Schumacher's movies add nothing to the character. Wayne's less bland in this movie than the last one, but that's not saying much. Clooney plays the worst Batman/Bruce Wayne of the series, but I did like the part when Batman smashes into Freeze, then it suddenly cuts to Batman lifting his cape to reveal an unconscious Freeze lying on the ground. Clooney would have been great if he got to play Batman in Batman Forever. But unfortunately Clooney's stuck playing the happy-go-lucky goof in this movie. I doubt Kilmer could've played a good Batman/Bruce Wayne in any Batman movie - not even Batman Begins. But I think that Clooney could have played a terrific Batman in Batman Begins - if he wasn't too old for the part, AND if he took the role seriously.I hate lots of things in this movie, especially the Batmobile (which has a disco ball in it). Another thing is that Batman & Robin are always equipped with boots that turn into ice skates - and that's BEFORE they ever heard of Mr. Freeze. I guess they prepare for everything - by the way, I'm being sarcastic. And the lamest goons I ever saw are in this movie, armed with hockey sticks. Then they play a rough hockey game with Robin, using a big diamond instead of a puck. And it looks fake whenever someone's airborne, like when Freeze throws people around. And I especially hate when Batman and Robin use improvised surfboards in the air. I guess Schumacher was trying real hard to make the two dorky superheroes look cool. And why did Freeze only shoot his ice gun at Batman's wrists? If he froze Batman's entire body, Batman would have NO CHANCE WHATSOEVER to escape. And later on, Freeze froze Robin's entire body, so Robin will die in eleven minutes unless he's thawed out. Freeze could also kill Batman easily - so why does Freeze say "I'll kill you later" and walk away? And there's statues of musclebound men on every street corner. And not a single thing in this movie is intentionally funny - except for when Ivy makes an amusing joke about a Poison Ivy action figure. And in the comics, Bane was a highly intelligent fellow, who could also snap people like twigs. In this movie he's a mindless drone who does nothing but growl and ball his fists. And this time the Batmobile's not driving up walls. Instead, we see the Batmobile doing something even more absurd - engaging in a high-speed chase along the torso of a huge statue. And there's sound effects when people slip or fall, like the sound gag in a Looney Tunes cartoon when someone slips on a banana peel. And the motorcycle race is lame, as is the "virtual simulation" of Alfred. And every action scene sucks. And Goldenthal's background music sounds like crap. And just like in Batman Forever, Batman changes into a completely ridiculous costume right before the final showdown with the bad guys. Why did he do that anyway? Who is he trying to impress? And the lowest of many low points is when Batman and Robin are driving two vehicles that look like snowmobiles. I guess they have all sorts of gizmos lying around the Batcave that they were all too pleased to try out in wintry conditions. And Bane was defeated WAY too easily. And as for the way Freeze found out Poison Ivy tried to kill his wife, I guess Batman goes around videotaping all of his costumed exploits. I can relate to that - I love watching myself on TV, and staring at my own reflection, and so on. And do Gotham's citizens ever wonder why their city looks COMPLETELY different every few years? And at the end credits, we get to hear the incredibly immoral R. Kelly sing a song called `Gotham City'. He must be singing about some other city, and not Gotham City the way I always imagined it.
summary: Do us all a favor Alfred, and DROP DEAD

reviewText: Batman and Robin is a fun, lighthearted movie that doesn't take itself too seriously like the second Burton film, Batman Returns.  The vision of this movie's filmakers was a balance between the Batman pathos and the campiness of the 60's series.  The sets were gorgeous.  Gotham City is depicted as it should be, a dark urban forest that both dominates and is dominated by the night.  The only groaners were Arkam Asylum that looked like a giant church organ that no one is his right mind would use as an asylum, and the Gotham Observatory, held like a bottle of Gatorade in the hands of a giant statue.Uma Thurman as Poison Ivy is precious, amazing, delectable, delicious.  She steals the show.  To paraphrase Comic Book Guy, "Best movie entrance EVER!"  The orchestration of the sixties hit "Poison Ivy" is great.George Clooney as Batman is, well, George Clooney.  He certainly looks the part, especially as bachelor Bruce Wayne, but as the Caped Crusader his relaxed demeanor as seen on E.R. and "O Brother Where Art Thou" is present though it should not be.  Clooney is surprisingly graceful in the costume, and does some very Batman-like flourishes with the cape.  And his scene with the dying Alfred is so touching, as well as flashbacks to his days as a boy in Wayne Manor with his father.Alicia Silverstone is cute, and she is fine in her role.  Chris O'Donnell is great as Robin, too.  I love Arnold's over the top presentation as Mr. Freeze.  It couldn't have been any other way.

reviewText: I didn't think this film is nearly as bad as everyone makes it to sound. Its not perfect, but none of the Batman movies (including the 1989 film) thus far have been as strong and excellent as the Spider-man series. However, I did find this film much more entertaining than the Batman Forever and Batman Returns films. Uma does a perfect portrayal of Poison Ivy. Arnold is great as Mr. Freeze. I also liked the addition of that big guy, Bane. Chris is "okay" as Robin (I'm not a fan of the character anyway). As for Alicia...well, I like her, but I didn't like the way her character was written for Batgirl. The background story just falls flat, so its not her fault. My problem is with George Clooney. He is so WRONG for the part as Batman. In fairness to him, Batman is a very dull and broody character. There's not much one can do to lighten him up without betraying the concept of Batman/Bruce Wayne. BUT at least with Michael Keaton, he brought some charm to the role. I noticed some people said the dialogue and story is cheesy, but the concept of heroes and villains dressing up in costumes is cheesy in itself so bring on the cheese! :) Overall, I thought the movie was pretty cool. There's lots of action and a little bit more girl power than the previous films. Its not better than 1989's Batman, but its still entertaining.

reviewText: For the fifth Batman feature, producers turned to then-hot tv actor George Clooney to follow in the bat-boots of West, Keaton, and Kilmer. Dubbed "BATMAN FAMILY VALUES" by some due to it's central message about the importance of maintaining strong, interpersonal ties with siblings and elders, this thrill-packed action spectacular remains as popular today as the summer it opened. More cerebral than previous installments, BATMAN & ROBIN boasts powerful performances, state-of-the-art effects and production design, and heart-pounding action sequences that rank among the finest ever put on film; to miss it would be criminal.

reviewText: Batman & Robin is probably tied with Armageddon on my list of worst movies ever made.  I cannot even start describing how bad it is.Maybe I should start with the poor casting and script.  George Clooney is not a convincing Batman, and he will probably be remembered as the George Lazenby of Batmen.  Michael Gough returns, and his character is actually essential to the plot now.  Arnold Schwarzenneger gave up some good roles to play Mr. Freeze, and it looks like he made a poor choice.  The Mr. Freeze of the comics was very cerebral, while the movie version is nothing like that.The script is just awful.  The dialogue is cliche and repetitive, with Mr. Freeze inserting the word "ice" in place of just about any imaginable curse word.  There are a lot of sub plots going on.  Batgirl wants to save Alfred, Mr. Freeze is trying to cure his wife, and Poison Ivy will stop at nothing to unleash her brand of environmental terror.  Everything is just so over the top that its hard to take the movie seriously.It's hard to see why Joel Schumacher dropped the ball so badly after he did a good job on Batman Forever.  The special effects and the style of the sets are very similar to those of the previous movie.  The only difference is that the pyrotechnics and sound effects are overdone and become annoying.  This movie seems to draw its influence from the campy 60's TV show more than the Batman comic.This movie is an insult to the Batman comic and a horrible waste of acting talent.  Watch this only as a study in how not to make an action movie.
summary: It doesn't get much worse than this

reviewText: The way people talk, you would think this movie is absolutely horrible.  It isn't.  I think people that talk down about Batman and Robin forget a few things.  First this movie was made in 1997, thats 14 years ago and that is like centuries in movie time.  I watched Batman and Robin today for the first time in, well, forever and I must say its visually stunning considering its time frame.  Also, the whole Batman Begins/Dark Knight thing marked a new start for Batman.  Do you remember the old television show Batman?  And then you had the movies, come on, a fat deformed man living in the sewers calling himself the penguin?  A guy running around in a latex suit calling himself Batman and a sidekick that started off wearing his old green and red circus suit and takes the name Robin? Jim Carrey as the Riddler? An over worked, under-appreciated office worker who falls like 10 stories, lives, and then sews together a suit and goes on a rampage as Cat Woman?  When this movie was made Batman was a bit of a corny super hero, not the well explained, dark, sensible, dramatic character that has been reborn in Begins/Knight.  So I can kind of let this movie slideGeorge Clooney plays a heck of a Batman; hes just a talented actor.  Chris O'Donnell in Forever and B&R; is just like Fred Durst, hes that annoying frat boy you just want to punch out, he really irritates me.  This movie has a pretty solid cast though, Uma Thurman, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Alicia Silverstone, Michael Gough...and this is a good thing, because I will agree that the writing is a little bad.  Corny jokes here and there (especially from Mr. Freeze) and the characters themselves are just enough to make you want to laugh (Poison Ivy's apparently WAY over-active sex drive/Bane being a complete moron).If it weren't for the overly flirtatious seductions of Poison Ivy I would say this is absolutely a kid's film.  Its just a little bit immature.  I enjoyed it for what its worth.  Its not so bad you can't watch it, but there are a lot of parts that will make you say Really?  Did the Governator just pop up out of a snow mobile with a freeze gun and say chill?! Is Arnold REALLY wearing Polar Bear slippers?!  I remember vaguely when this first came out in theaters my mom took me to see it, and with a young mindset I thought it was the greatest thing ever, but now I can slightly see why people have such animosity toward it.  Its a guilty pleasure thats for sure.  Batman and Robin has its parts, but as a whole I wouldn't say its a strong movie.  I would suggest just avoiding Batman, Returns, Forever, B&R;, and jumping straight to Begins.
summary: Ok people its not THAT bad...

I'm glad that Bill Finger never saw it, and I really hope Bob Kane never did.

reviewText: I'm just not going to reiterate what countless others have said about this movie. Simply said, this is the movie that singlehandedly ran the "Batman" franchise off the tracks and for a long time was considered the end of the franchise, until Christopher Nolan boldly resurrected the franchise with the magnificent "Batman Begins" in June 2005.There's just so many things about it it would probably take me pages to list them all. The screenplay, written by Akiva Goldsman (who has proven himself to be a capable screenwriter in other movies), is just the primary offender. The screenplay is also atrocious in dialogue, mostly relegated for the badly-miscast Arnold Schwartzenegger as Mr. Freeze and it beats us over the head with its absurd plot twists and sickening melodrama. Superhero movies are definitely not Akiva Goldsman's strongest suit. The movie is also much gaudier and colorful, to the point where it seems more like a three-ring circus act rather than a proper Batman movie. Director Joel Schumacher (who also has some good films under his belt, such as "The Client" and "Tiger Land") just phones it in and doesn't aim for any sort of restraint or subtlety.The good points? well, most of the actors escape unscathed, although this is one film they'll prefer to forget on their resumes. George Clooney does fine, just playing himself wearing the Batman costume and acting like a faux Cary Grant when he's out of the suit. Chris O'Donnell is fine and so is Alicia Silverstone (even though the script absurdly rewrites her origin as Alfred's niece and not as Commissioner Gordon's daughter in the comics), but Arnold Schwartznegger is just badly miscast. Every time he's on screen, I just grind my teeth in agony over the bad one-liners the script gives him. The only real standouts are Uma Thurman who vamps it up wonderfully as Poison Ivy and looks great in the wig and skintight outfits and Michael Gough does inject his trademark class into a rather thankless reprise of Alfred.When Warner Brothers adapted the DVD format, "Batman & Robin" (as well as the four other Batman movies) were a few of the first films to see the light on DVD, albeit in stripped down and barebones versions. With the impending release of "Batman Begins" in summer 2005, Warner Brothers announced that all four Batman movies would receive new digital transfers and be released on DVD with all-new bonus material. This is "Batman & Robin"'s second offering on DVD, and does it warrant a double-dip? Yes and no.If you hate "Batman & Robin", you're liable to skip this and just pick up the first two "Batman" special editions. However, if you're a fan of the film, this is definitely worth a purchase in terms of better video and great extras.In comparison to the 1997 edition, the 2005 transfer of "Batman & Robin" is a significant improvement. The previous edition was on a dual-sided, single layer disc, while this edition is housed on a dual-layer disc and is progressively encoded. The colors were messy and runny in the 1997 edition, but the 2005 edition corrects those errors. Detail is better, as well as overall compression and color stabilization. This edition isn't quite an improvement as the first "Batman" movie was, but as such it was a newer release and didn't warrant a more extensive transfer. That said, it looks gorgeous even with all the gaudy colors on display and looks impressive, even though there are a few instances of film artifacts.The Dolby Digital 5.1 track is the same offering as on the 1997 edition, but even then it sounded great without any major problems. There is a most significant audio upgrade in terms of a higher-bitrate DTS 5.1 surround track. The Dolby track is just as noisy and bombastic as the film demands, with frequent surround activity, deep bass and clear dialogue. Elliot Goldenthal's music has fine stereo spread and sounds great. The DTS track is marginally louder but is just as clear and precise as the Dolby track, but both lack the subtler ambience and sense of spaciousness that "Batman Begins" had. Still, this is a reference-quality transfer. Also included is a French 5.1 dub (which is preferable since you won't have to be subjected to the awful dialogue) and the film has optional subtitles in English, French and Spanish.Like the previous three "Batman" movies, the first disc has the movie, a full-length audio commentary by Joel Schumacher, and the film's theatrical trailer (presented anamorphically with stereo sound). The audio commentary by Schumacher is decent, but does tend to be self-congratulatory in places. He does make a discreet apology to those who didn't like the film and asserts that he fully knew what he was doing when he signed on to do "Batman & Robin". It's a boon for those who want to hear Schumacher's apology, and it too is an alternative audio track to listen to the movie with in that it masks most of the horrible dialogue. The trailer is decent, but it makes the movie to be much better than what it turned out to be. The film is divided into 41 chapters and the main menu is animated against a segment of Elliot Goldenthal's different Batman theme.The second disc of extras mirror that of the previous three releases. There's the sixth part of "The Cinematic Saga of Batman", which covers the release and critical drubbing the film got. Also included is a similar heroes and villains section that covers the different heroes and villains of the movies, such as Commissioner Gordon, the Dynamic Duo, Batgirl, Bane, Poison Ivy and Mr. Freeze. Almost all of these featurettes feature new interviews with Joel Schumacher, producer Peter MacGregor-Scott, Alicia Silverstone, Chris O'Donnell, executive producer Michael Uslan, and Akiva Goldsman (unsurprisingly, there are no new interviews with Schwartznegger, Thurman or Clooney -- perhaps they're too embarassed to talk about B&R; now). In addition to the "Beyond Batman" gallery, which covers production design, makeup design, vehicle design, costume design, and visual effects (no featurette about the musical score here) and the usual plethora of movie-related music videos, there is also a brief deleted scene included, "Alfred's Lost Love". It clears up a plot point in the film, but is nothing extraordinary and worth giving a cursory glance. The menus on the second disc are still, with only the main menu featuring a segment of the score. The set is packaged in a double-width Amaray keep case without inserts of any kind.If you hate this movie with a burning passion, then avoid this disc like the plague. If you're enamored with the film because it's unintentionally funny (or if you actually think it's good), then by all means get it because the extras are extensive and the transfer is a noticeable improvement over the initial release. But if you're a completist, then it'd be preferable if you buy the Complete Batman Anthology set so you won't be heckled for having such a bad film in your collection.
